author: Deleted User

author: huntingisland
content: Are there any EIPs for gas price adjustment slated for Berlin?

author: huntingisland
content: IMO we need to greatly reduce the gas cost of any operations that don't grow state or otherwise have a negative relationship with state growth

author: huntingisland
content: Anything to tune stuff like simple ERC-20 transfers such as Tether when the ops they are using aren't impacting state growth

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Not skated for Berlin. But there are people working on a couple.

author: huntingisland
content: thanks!

author: huntingisland
content: I think 50 gwei or more gas price is likely to be around for quite some time and probably get worse if we get a bull run here

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Looking at something like ERC 20. If someone did a profile of the gas vs runtime that would be really helpful. There is general agreement around reducing gas costs. We just need to be careful not to create DoS vectors which involves a lot of profiling the different client implementations.

author: huntingisland
content: I guess the alternative is to increase gas price for all the problematic state instructions and then increase ETH gas limit. That might be a better approach.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Could be. There has been some benchmark work from Starware and Matterlabs for a comprehensive overhaul. I am not totally sure about the progress though.

author: Deleted User
content: Version 1.1 of Oil proposal just published by <@!709470782035722310> . It takes into account the use-case of meta-transactions: https://ethresear.ch/t/oil-adding-a-second-fuel-source-to-the-evm-pre-eip-v1-1/7425

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content:
<alexberegszaszi> That is only about repricing the precompiles and verifying the reduction proposed by EIP-2046 is safe (or a further reduction would be in place).
That work, AFAIK, is not proposing to reduce the cost of any other opcode. (re @eth1x_bridge_bot: <James Hancock> Could be. There has been some benchmark work from Starware and Matterlabs for a comprehensive overhaul. I am not totally sure about the progress though.)
